title: How to Make an Autumn‐Themed Forest Collage

steps.headline: Buy or find some magazines that are nature themed with autumnal trees and animals.
steps.description: You can tell if the trees are autumn themed by looking at the leaves. They should be coloured red, gold, brown, magenta, yellow or even slightly blue.You can try finding a nature magazine from an autumn month or week to find pictures of autumnal animals, plants and trees.

steps.headline: Cut out the best images of autumnal trees, animals and plants that you have found.
steps.description: Start thinking about roughly where you will put them. You will be putting the trees in the background in your collage, so keep that in mind while planning it out.

steps.headline: Place and stick the trees into the background.
steps.description: They need to be in a row with the trunks 3/4 from the bottom of the page. Try to have a range of different coloured leaved trees. A pattern of red and orange looks better than a row of one colour.

steps.headline: Paint the path under the tree trunks.
steps.description: Your picture should look like the trees are towering over the path and bursting in colour. If your picture does not look like the trees are towering over the path, you may have placed them at an angle rather than straight, which ruins the perspective.

steps.headline: Add in the animals and plants.
steps.description: The plants can go in front of the trees, and the animals can go in front of the trees or in the branches if it is a bird or climbing animal. Don't get too carried away with the animals. You only need about ten of them.

steps.headline: Colour in the gaps between the trees blue as sky.
steps.description: The sky is not a blue strip across the top of the page. In pictures, it comes all the way down until it meets the ground. If you don't have gaps in between the trees, don't worry. It is not a crucial part and you can skip this step.

steps.headline: Add some finishing touches.
steps.description: Maybe you could paint the path brown or give the tree trunks a sheen of brown acrylic paint. Acrylic paint offers a solid texture that works well in this kind of collage.

steps.headline: Leave the paint to dry for twenty minutes.
steps.description: Acrylic paint drys very quickly, so you don't need to wait long. While the paint is drying, do not touch or smudge the picture.

steps.headline: Admire your work.
steps.description: Put the picture up on a wall or notice board, or maybe post a photo of it on your blog or social media.

text: Buy or find some magazines that are nature themed with autumnal trees and animals. You can tell if the trees are autumn themed by looking at the leaves. They should be coloured red, gold, brown, magenta, yellow or even slightly blue.You can try finding a nature magazine from an autumn month or week to find pictures of autumnal animals, plants and trees. Cut out the best images of autumnal trees, animals and plants that you have found. Start thinking about roughly where you will put them. You will be putting the trees in the background in your collage, so keep that in mind while planning it out. Place and stick the trees into the background. They need to be in a row with the trunks 3/4 from the bottom of the page. Try to have a range of different coloured leaved trees. A pattern of red and orange looks better than a row of one colour. Paint the path under the tree trunks. Your picture should look like the trees are towering over the path and bursting in colour. If your picture does not look like the trees are towering over the path, you may have placed them at an angle rather than straight, which ruins the perspective. Add in the animals and plants. The plants can go in front of the trees, and the animals can go in front of the trees or in the branches if it is a bird or climbing animal. Don't get too carried away with the animals. You only need about ten of them. Colour in the gaps between the trees blue as sky. The sky is not a blue strip across the top of the page. In pictures, it comes all the way down until it meets the ground. If you don't have gaps in between the trees, don't worry. It is not a crucial part and you can skip this step. Add some finishing touches. Maybe you could paint the path brown or give the tree trunks a sheen of brown acrylic paint. Acrylic paint offers a solid texture that works well in this kind of collage. Leave the paint to dry for twenty minutes. Acrylic paint drys very quickly, so you don't need to wait long. While the paint is drying, do not touch or smudge the picture. Admire your work. Put the picture up on a wall or notice board, or maybe post a photo of it on your blog or social media.
